head.title: Three-Dimensional Dendritic Cu–Co–P Electrode by One-Step Electrodeposition on a Hydrogen Bubble Template for Hydrogen Evolution Reaction | ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

meta.content: Three-Dimensional Dendritic Cu–Co–P Electrode by One-Step Electrodeposition on a Hydrogen Bubble Template for Hydrogen Evolution Reaction

A Cu–Co–P electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) was designed with a dendritic and porous foam structure. Fabricated by one-step electrodeposition with binary alloy on a hydrogen bubble template, the porous foam exhibited remarkable HER activity in alkaline conditions. Cu was the dominant element in the core and shell region and acted for 3D structure formation. Cu–Co formed in the shell part and acted as an active region for hydrogen evolution reaction. Also, as the amount of P increased in the Cu–Co–P foams, the pore numbers, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA), and the HER activity were enhanced. The improved activity is believed to originate from the charge separation between the negatively charged P (δ–) and positively charged Cu and Co (δ+), the larger ECSA, and increased porosity.

div.span: KEYWORDS:

span.p: A dendritic copper−cobalt-phosphide porous foam shows remarkably enhanced catalytic activity for hydrogen evolution reaction thanks to the incorporation of phosphide.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, 2H
+
+ 2e
–
→ H
2
) is a fundamental process that is critical for water splitting. Despite the importance of HER, the high overpotential of HER at conventional water-splitting cathodes yields slow reaction kinetics and decreased water-splitting reaction efficiency.
(1−3)
Generally, precious metal-based catalysts, such as Pt and Pt-group metals, are considered ideal for HER. They allow very low overpotentials with fast kinetics in both basic and acidic conditions.
(4)
However, although these precious metals are the most effective HER catalysts, their high cost and scarcity are serious problems.
(2−8)
Therefore, replacement of precious metal catalysts with abundant and nonprecious materials is highly desirable.
(9,10)

Recently, transition-metal sulfides, carbides, and phosphides have emerged as alternative catalysts for HER due to their high abundance and considerably high activity.
(11,12)
Transition-metal phosphides (TMPs), such as Cu–P,
(13,14)
Co–P,
(11,15−17)
Ni–P,
(18,19)
and Mo–P,
(7,20)
have recently been widely researched as HER electrocatalysts. Among these TMPs, Co–P can electrocatalytically generate hydrogen gas with low overpotentials and is suitable for applications such as fuel cells,
(21,22)
metal–air batteries,
(23,24)
and water electrolysis.
(11,15,16)
The typical synthesis methods for TMPs are wet chemistry
(11,25)
and vapor-phase deposition,
(19,26)
many of which entail complex processes and require high-temperature treatment.
(11)
Therefore, a simple and low-cost fabrication method will always see its great value for practical applications.

Electrodeposition as one of the most suitable methods for TMP synthesis offers many advantages. First, the composition and morphology of the resulting electrocatalysts can be controlled easily by adjusting the electrodeposition potential, time, and electrolyte composition.
(27−29)
Second, as an inherent feature, the electrocatalysts fabricated by electrodeposition usually exhibit excellent electrical conductivity.
(30,31)
Third, because electrodeposition directly deposits catalysts on the substrate, the ohmic contact resistance between the catalyst layer and substrate is significantly lower than the conventional powder-type catalysts, which rely on poorly conductive polymeric binders such as poly(tetrafluoroethylene) (PTFE) and nafion to prevent catalyst detachment. Fourth, electrodeposition allows the formation of TMPs without heat treatment. By starting with a solution containing a P source such as NaH
2
PO
2
, the TMP electrocatalyst can be directly deposited on the substrate and immediately utilized without additional (and often detrimental) processing.
(32)

An electrode having a structure that can promote reaction kinetics and has a large surface area is advantageous for catalytic reactions. Because HER is a gas evolution reaction, the hydrogen gas generated by water electrolysis must be quickly removed from the electrode; otherwise, it may accumulate at the electrode surface, block the active sites, and decrease the kinetics of HER. Interestingly, one can also take advantage of such hydrogen bubbles and use them as templates in electrodeposition processes for convenient creation of 3D dendritic-structured electrodes.
(33,34)
Upon the application of a high current to the substrate electrode, metal ions are reduced and electrodeposited on the substrate at a very high rate, along with the generation of many hydrogen bubbles that result in the formation of abundant pores. Such three-dimensional (3D) porous structures are considered ideal electrode structures because their large surface may offer more active sites, and their high porosity may also promote the penetration of reactants to the inner electrode and facilitate the escape of the hydrogen gas generated by water electrolysis.

Herein, we report a simple one-step electrodeposition process for the fabrication of Cu–Co–P porous foams using hydrogen bubbles formed in situ as templates. By simply controlling the concentrations of P sources in the solution, we are able to control the loading of P in the Cu–Co–P foams through the electrodeposition process. The resulting foam structure exhibits an extremely large surface area, which offers abundant active sites for electrocatalytic reaction, and micrometer-sized pore networks, which greatly facilitate the mass transport.
(35)
As a result, the HER activity of the Cu–Co–P foams was significantly improved over that without P.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.h3:
Preparation of Cu–Co–P
x
Foams by Electrodeposition
div.div:
Cu–Co–P
x
foam were prepared by electrodeposition in an electrolyte composed of 0.04 M CuSO
4
, 0.4 M CoSO
4
, 1 M NaCl, 1 M H
2
SO
4
, and different concentrations (
x
= 10, 20, 30, and 40 mM) of NaH
2
PO
2
. The H
2
SO
4
act as a source of hydrogen bubble template, and NaCl act as a catalytic effect of the intermediate compound, CuCl.
(36)
Stainless steel foil (type 304, 0.025 mm, Alfa Aesar) was used as deposition substrate (working area 0.25 cm
2
) as working electrode. Two electrode systems were configured with Pt mesh as a counter electrode (distance between working electrode and counter electrode was 1 cm). Prior to electrodeposition, the substrate that was mechanically polished was degreased by ultrasonication in an acetone, ethanol, and deionized water for 15 min, respectively. The Cu–Co–P
x
porous foam was deposited by constant current of 2 A/cm
2
for 20 s in the prepared electrolytic solution without magnetic stirring at room temperature. The prepared samples were thoroughly rinsed with deionized water before drying in convection oven at 70 °C. To compare with Cu–Co–P
x
foam, the comparison electrode used commercial Pt/C (40 wt. %) with Nafion dispersed on stainless steel foil (working area 0.25 cm
2
).

div.h3: Preparation of Cu and Cu–Co Foam by Electrodeposition
div.div:
Cu foam was prepared by electrodeposition in an electrolyte composed of 0.04 M CuSO
4
, 1 M NaCl, and 1 M H
2
SO
4
. Cu–Co foam was prepared in 0.04 M CuSO
4
, 0.4 M CoSO
4
, 1 M NaCl, and 1 M H
2
SO
4
. Both Cu foam and Cu–Co foam were electrodeposited on stainless steel foil (working area 0.25 cm
2
) at 2 A/cm
2
for 20 s.

All the electrochemical measurements were analyzed by using potentiostat (VSP, Biologic). The electrochemical properties of the Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foam toward HER were carried out in a three-electrode cell with N
2
-purged 1 M KOH electrolyte at room temperature. The Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P porous foams deposited on stainless steel foil were used as working electrode. The counter electrode was graphite rod because platinum is not a suitable electrode for HER test, and reference electrode was Ag/AgCl (1 M KCl).
(37)

All potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE, V
RHE
= V versus RHE) using the Nernst equation (
E
RHE
=
E
Ag/AgCl
+ 0.236 + 0.059 pH). The activity of HER was examined by linear sweep voltammetry. The LSV curves were tested from 0 to −0.25 V vs V
RHE
at a scan rate of 5 mV/s. All electrochemical results were 85% IR-corrected. The stability tests were investigated by using constant current at 10 mA/cm
2
for 6 h.

Electrochemical surface area (ECSA) was obtained from the electrochemical double layer capacitance using cyclic voltammetry at a different scan rate (2.5–40 mV/s) in nonfaradaic region in 1 M KOH. The ECSA was calculated by using the following equation:
(1)
The
C
s
value means smooth plane capacitance for metal surface, and it is 40 uF/cm
2
.
(38)
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was carried out in 1 M KOH solution. The EIS was measured in the frequency range from 200 kHz to 10 Hz with an amplitude of 14.14 mV, and applied potential was −0.15 V.

The morphologies and compositions were analyzed by field emission SEM (JEOL, JSM-7001F) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer. Bright field transmission electron microscopic (BFTEM) images were acquired by a JEOL JEM 2100F at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an X-ray diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation (D8 Advance, Bruker). Scan range was 30–80°, and scan speed was 1°/min. XPS was examined on a XPS spectrometer (K-Alpha, Thermo VG Scientific). XPS depth profiles were collected with a Ar
+
ion beam bombardment with 2k eV. Wettability of porous foam was characterized measuring the contact angles of D.I. water by contact measurement machine (NPT103, EPSM).

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
As illustrated in
Figure
1
a, the Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
porous foams were fabricated by one-step electrodeposition, where
x
is the concentration of the P source and its value varies from 10 to 20, 30, and 40 mM. Specifically, a high current density was applied to the substrate in 0.04 M CuSO
4
, 0.4 M CoSO
4
, 1 M NaCl, 1 M H
2
SO
4
, and different concentrations of NaH
2
PO
2
. When the current was applied to the working electrode, Cu–Co–P
x
foams were electrodeposited on the stainless steel foil. Simultaneously, hydrogen bubbles are vigorously produced at the electrode surface. These act as templates to build the porous nanostructure. The electrodeposition reactions are as follows:
(2)
(3)
(4)
When the current is applied to the substrate electrode, the Cu
2+
and Co
2+
are reduced to metallic Cu and Co. At the same time, H
2
PO
2
–
from NaH
2
PO
2
is reduced to P in the Cu–Co–P
x
foams. To synthesize Cu–Co–P compound from metallic Cu/Co and element P, diffusion process of P is required. Robinson reported that P atoms diffuse into metallic cobalt crystal lattice and form Co–P phase.
(39)
Also, since Cu and Co had a similar ionic radius and electronegativity, Cu could substitute the Co matrix in Co–P phase in the electrodeposited Cu–Co–P
x
foams.
(40)
Therefore, the Cu–Co–P
x
is present in the form of a compound.
(41)

div.p:
Figure 1. (a) Schematic of illustration of the Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foam by using the hydrogen bubble template. The SEM image of Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foam and cross section (b, f) 0 mM, (c, g) 10 mM, (d, h) 20 mM, and (e, i) 30 mM NaH
2
PO
2
in electrodeposition solution.

div.div:
Figure
1
b–i show the top-view and cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foams fabricated with different concentrations of NaH
2
PO
2
. The pore sizes formed on the electrode are approximately 5–10 μm and depend on the size of the hydrogen bubbles. The areal proportion of pores and the number of surface pores are increased by increases in the concentration of NaH
2
PO
2
because of the influence of P on Cu–Co–P
x
(
Figure S1
). As the electrodeposition begins without NaH
2
PO
2
, Cu and Co with relatively low HER activities are electrodeposited. On the contrary, the electrochemically deposited electrode with NaH
2
PO
2
shows high HER activity through the P effect, as shown in CoP
(11,15−17)
and CuP.
(13,14)
Therefore, compared to the Cu–Co foam, the Cu–Co–P
x
foams have more surface pores and higher areal proportions of pores because of the increased hydrogen bubbles. In addition, vigorous HER decreases the catalyst layer thickness because many more electrons are consumed in hydrogen gas generation than in the electrodeposition of Cu, Co, and P. When the concentration of NaH
2
PO
2
is increased in the electrodeposition solution, the thicknesses of the Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foams are decreased from 17 to 12 μm, as shown in
Figure
1
f–i. In addition, the amount of mass loading before and after electrodeposition on the substrate is shown in
Figure
2
a. When the concentration of NaH
2
PO
2
is increased from 0 to 30 mM, the mass loading is decreased from 1.2 to 0.56 mg/cm
2
. However, using >40 mM of NaH
2
PO
2
does not allow porous foam structure formation because of the extremely vigorous HER (
Figure S2
).
(42)

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Change of mass loading before/after electrodeposition of Cu–Co–P
x
. (b) Compositional change of Cu–Co–P
x
by electrodeposition method using different NaH
2
PO
2
concentration. (c) TEM-EDS elemental mapping images of Co (yellow), Cu (red), and P (cyan) in dendritic Cu–Co–P.

div.div:
Figure
2
b shows the compositional changes of Cu, Co, and P. As the concentration of NaH
2
PO
2
is elevated, Co is decreased, but Cu and P are increased. According to a previous report, the reduction overpotential of Cu was decreased as the concentration of H
2
PO
2
–
increased.
(43)
Smaller electrodeposition overpotential corresponds to higher Cu electrodeposition rates and thus faster copper deposition. Conversely, as the concentration of H
2
PO
2
–
increased, Co reduction was slowed.
(32)
Therefore, compositional changes occur in the Cu–Co–P
x
foams with increasing concentrations of NaH
2
PO
2
during electrodeposition, which means that the Cu increases and Co decreases.

The dendritic shapes of the Cu–Co–P
x
nanostructures are confirmed through transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (
Figure
2
c). The dendritic structure with identical dimensions (stem diameter = 20 nm; sprig diameter = 16 nm on average) is grown on the substrate electrode by the bubble template. The constituent elements of the nanostructures are identified as Cu, Co, and P by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The stems of the thorn structures are Cu and Co while the sprigs comprise Co, according to the line-profile mapping results in
Figure S3
. P is uniformly distributed on stems and sprigs. According to one report,
(44)
the difference of nucleation rate during deposition induces core–shell-like structures. The Cu nucleation rate is relatively higher than that of Co, causing Cu island formation early in a deposition. As the electrodeposition progresses, the Cu(II) ions near the substrate electrode are rapidly reduced to metallic Cu, and the ion concentration is depleted. The nucleation of Co thus begins by wrapping the Cu islands. The result is a core–shell-like structure with a relatively Cu-rich core and Co-rich shell.
(45)

The electrocatalytic performance of Cu, Cu–Co, and Cu–Co–P
x
foam which fabricated with various concentrations of NaH
2
PO
2
was investigated. The foams were fabricated under the same electrodeposition condition (refer to
Experimental Section
), and their surface SEM images are shown in
Figure S4
. The HER electroactivities of the Cu, Cu–Co, and Cu–Co–P
x
foams are compared to that of the conventional Pt/C, which is one of the best HER catalysts. The HER catalytic performance was improved by Co-plating rather than by Cu growth alone, and the activity was further improved by incorporating P, as shown in
Figure
3
a. Also, it showed the effects of Co and P. The Cu foam had a high overpotential of 382 mV at 10 mA/cm
2
. The effect of Co deposition was observed by comparing the Cu and Cu–Co foams. The overpotential was reduced by ∼105 mV from 382 to 277 mV with Co deposition. The effect of P was observed by comparing the Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foams (
x
= 10, 20, 30, and 40 mM), as shown in
Figure S5
. The P-containing Cu–Co–P
x
foams were uniformly improved in HER activity regarding the onset potential and overpotential compared to Cu–Co. Especially, the Cu–Co–P
20
foam exhibited the lowest overpotential, which was 138 mV at 10 mA/cm
2
. Comparing Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
, the decrease in overpotential was 139 mV, which was the greatest decrease observed among the tested Cu–Co–P
x
foam. Cu–Co–P
20
foam showed a Tafel slope of 48 mV/dec (
Figure
3
b), which follows Volmer–Heyrovsky mechanism as reported in the literature.
(46,47)
This value was similar to Pt/C. Also, the overpotentials of the Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
(
x
= 10, 20, 30, and 40 mM) foams are shown in
Figure
3
c. Compared to Pt/C, which has the overpotential of 35 mV and the Tafel slope of 49 mV/dec, the Cu–Co–P
20
porous foam had a relatively higher overpotential. However, the nonprecious metal complex of Cu–Co–P
20
foam exhibits better HER performance than the recently reported CuP or CoP electrocatalysts except for electrocatalysts synthesized by using foam-based substrate, such as Cu foam, Ni foam. (
Table S1
).

div.p:
Figure 3. HER in N
2
-saturated 1 M KOH. (a) LSV curves of Cu, Cu–Co, and Cu–Co–P
20
foams recorded at a scan rate of 5 mV/s in the potential range of 0 to −0.25 V vs RHE. (b) Tafel slope of electrocatalyst with different concentration of NaH
2
PO
2
(0, 10, 20, 30, and 40 mM) from HER polarizations. (c) Comparison of electrochemical surface area (ECSA) at nonfaradaic region (refer to
Figure S6
) and measured overpotential at 10 mA/cm
2
. (d) Durability test of Cu–Co–P
20
foam at 10 mA/cm
2
.

div.div:
The electrochemical surface areas (ECSAs) of the Cu–Co–P
x
foams were calculated by the double-layer capacitance (
C
dl
). To obtain the
C
dl
, we performed cyclic voltammetry in the nonfaradaic region at different scan rates, as shown in
Figure S6
. The
C
dl
values of Cu–Co–P
x
for
x
= 0, 10, 20, 30, and 40 mM are 1.65, 3.24, 3.50, 2.7, and 1.61 mF, respectively. The ECSA was calculated as ECSA =
C
dl
/
C
s
(smooth plane capacitance for metal surface;
C
s
= 40 mF/cm
2
). Cu–Co–P
20
has the largest ECSA of 87.5 cm
2
. The other samples with
x
= 0, 10, 30, and 40 mM have those of 41.25, 81, 67.5, and 40.25 cm
2
, respectively, as shown in
Figure
3
c.

To obtain the charge transfer resistance (
R
ct
), we recorded the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) by dynamic potential (
P
) EIS at −150 mV vs reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), in
Figure S7a
. The
R
ct
were 1052, 53.9, 8.14, 10.12, and 16.12 Ω at 0, 10, 20, 30, and 40 mM NaH
2
PO
2
, respectively, in
Figure S7b
; Cu–Co–P
20
thus showed the lowest resistance. However,
R
ct
is sensitive to the surface area because catalysts with larger surface areas appear to have smaller
R
ct
.
(48,49)
Therefore, the surface area-corrected charge transfer resistance (
R
cct
) was calculated by using ECSA in
Figure S7b
. The overall tendency was similar; however, for NaH
2
PO
2
≥ 20 mM, a difference between
R
ct
and
R
cct
was found. The
R
cct
of Cu–Co–P
x
with
x
= 20, 30, and 40 mM were decreased to 0.71, 0.68, and 0.64 KΩ cm
2
, respectively. These results mean that the increase of P in Cu–Co–P
x
foams increases the HER activities by decreasing the catalyst resistances. This means that the resistance is decreased by P doping effects. Cu–Co–P
40
has the lowest resistance but lacks the foam morphology.

Among the factors determining catalytic performance, durability is as important as activity. In order to confirm the durability of the proposed foam catalyst for HER, a hydrogen generation experiment was conducted in galvanostatic conditions at 10 mA/cm
2
(
Figure
3
d). Cu–Co–P
20
shows insignificant changes in polarization after 6 h. After the durability testing, the overpotential of the Cu–Co–P
20
catalyst is changed from 138 to 144 mV, an increase of only 4.3%. The graphs and photographs in
Figure
3
d show that hydrogen gas is continuously generated during the durability test. Another durability test technique, repeatedly LSV, was conducted to check the cycle property in
Figure S8
. Cycling stability has been tested by continuous cyclic voltammetry between 0.0 and −0.2 V (vs RHE) for 1000 cycles in 1 M KOH. As shown in
Figure S8
, the current density of the as-synthesized Cu–Co–P
20
exhibits no serious degradation and is observed to maintain about 95% of the initial performance after 1000 cycles, which suggests the presence of good cycling performance and stability. After the durability test by the cycle test, the CuCoP
20
was analyzed by SEM, TEM, and XPS.
Figure S9a
shows a SEM image of the CuCoP
20
surface after CV test, revealing the maintaince of porous morphology and dendritic shape. Although a slight increase in pore size is shown, the overall shape of the catalyst layer can be seen to be maintained without significant change even if the HER reaction proceeds for a long time. Also, TEM images in
Figure S9b
indicated dendritic structure with uniformly distributed Cu, Co, and P after durability test.

The Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
foams have similar X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns in
Figure
4
a. Both show peaks corresponding to metallic Co (JCPDS: 015-0806) and Cu (JCPDS: 001-1242). All sharp peaks of the XRD patterns of the Cu–Co foam are well matched with those of metallic Cu, with lattice constants of
a
= 3.5970 Å and
c
= 3.5970 Å, and metallic Co, with lattice constants of
a
= 3.5447 Å and
c
= 3.5447 Å. The Cu–Co–P
20
foam has identical peak positions, meaning that peaks for P are not observed. This phenomenon could be observed at low at. % of P in TMPs. According to Robinson’s report,
(39)
only metallic Co peaks in XRD were observed at low P at. %. However, the intensity of the Cu and Co peaks is changed. In comparing the peak intensity of Cu and Co, the intensity of Co in the Cu–Co–P
20
foam is weaker, and that of Cu is stronger. This is consistent with the EDS results from
Figure
2
b.

div.p:
Figure 4. Electronic properties of phosphide. (a) XRD pattern of Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
foams. (b–d) High-resolution core level XPS spectra of Cu 2p
3/2
, Co 2p
3/2
, and P 2p
3/2
of as-prepared Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
foams.

div.div:
The elemental composition of Cu–Co–P was additionally supported by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS survey spectrum shown in
Figure S10
clearly indicated the presence of Cu, Co, and P. The high-resolution spectra of Cu 2p and Co 2p are shown in
Figure S11
. The Cu 2p
3/2
in both Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
was observed as metallic Cu (Cu
0
(932.65 eV) and Cu
δ+
(932.95 eV)) and oxidized Cu
2+
(933.15 eV and 933.3 eV). The Co 2p
3/2
in both Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
was observed as metallic Co (Co
0
(778.25 eV) and Co
δ+
(778.55 eV)) and oxidized Co
2+
/Co
3+
(781.9 eV/779.7 eV and 782.4 eV/780.3 eV) with satellite (786.7 eV and 787.2 eV). The oxidized metals are common when the TMPs are exposed to air condition.
(50)
When comparing Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
20
, binding energy shift of Cu and Co was observed in the positive direction. To clearly observe the binding energy shift, only the metallic region of 2p
3/2
was selectively shown in
Figure
4
b and c. The chemical states of Cu 2p
3/2
, Co 2p
3/2
, and P 2p
3/2
are obtained by peak fitting of the high-resolution spectrum (
Figure
4
b–d).
Figure
4
b shows the peak of Cu 2p
3/2
in the Cu–Co–P
20
foam at 933.0 eV, while that in Cu–Co foam is at 932.7 eV. In the Co 2p spectra (
Figure
4
c), the single peak at 778.55 eV corresponds to Co in Cu–Co–P
20
foam, and the single peak at 778.25 eV corresponds to Co in Cu–Co foam. In both high-resolution spectra of Cu and Co on the catalyst electrode with P, the peaks are shifted toward higher energies. The high-resolution spectrum of P 2p is divided into two types of phosphide species of oxidized and elemental P. The reason that oxidized P was observed is the surface passivation.
(50,51)
The P 2p spectral peaks from Cu–Co–P appear at 133.9 eV and 130 eV and are negatively shifted by −0.2 eV relative to the known position of elemental P (130.2 eV).
(52)
To confirm the change of chemical state of Cu–Co–P
20
after the durability test, we measured the XPS in
Figure S12
. No other change of component was observed in Cu and Co. The Cu
δ+
in Cu 2p
3/2
was 932.75 eV and Co
δ+
in Co 2p
3/2
was 778.45 eV, which meant that the chemical state of Cu and Co was well maintained compared with those before the durability test. In contrast, a slight change of P was observed. The XPS intensity of P in Cu–Co–P
20
slightly decreased the after stability test in alkaline conditions. According to Jan P. Hofmann’s group,
(51)
P has a tendency to preferentially dissolve in HER under alkaline conditions. However, the decrease in trace amount of P did not significantly reduce the HER activity even after the durability test in which hydrogen was continuously generated. The introduction of P into metal or metal oxide changes the electronic structure that determines the catalytic properties.
(53)
This suggests that partial electron transfer from the Cu/Co cations to P is enhanced by the introduction of the secondary element of P in Cu–Co. This means that Cu and Co have relatively positive charges (δ
+
) while P has a relatively negative charge (δ
–
) in the Cu–Co–P foams. The P sites are not inert, but direct participants in the HER. Liu et al. reported the density functional theory (DFT) calculation showing that protons could be trapped by the small negative charge of P atoms on the surfaces of metal phosphides, which induced high activity toward the dissociation of H
2
, which prevented the aggravation of HER because of the high coverage of strongly coupled H atoms.
(54)
In addition, according to the results of Wang’s group, the surfaces terminated with P in metal phosphates can increase the active edge to HER and show high activity.
(55)
These results are similar to the behavior of edges from S in MoS
2
.
(56)
Therefore, we concluded that the addition of suitable P compensates for the poor activity of Cu–Co. P induces the electrical state change described above, thereby preventing changes in the ohmic potential and enabling efficient utilization of the active material.

The Cu–Co and Cu–Co–P
x
foams fabricated using hydrogen bubble templates had low contact angles of ∼33–34°, as shown in
Figure S13
. This means that the foams have hydrophilic properties, which promote the fast penetration of electrolyte in micrometer-sized pores, which accelerates the HER.
(57)
Consequently, the Cu–Co–P porous foam fabricated by the hydrogen bubble template is an advantageous structure with large active surface areas, hydrophilic micrometer-sized pore networks, and excellent HER catalytic performance.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Herein, Cu–Co–P
x
porous foams were successfully fabricated by a hydrogen bubble-templated one-step electrodeposition method as HER electrocatalysts. Cu played an important role for fabrication of three-dimensionally porous structure, and Cu–Co was used as active electrocatalyst for HER. For the various tested concentrations of NaH
2
PO
2
in the electrodeposition solution, the Cu–Co–P
20
exhibited the highest HER activity with the overpotential of 138 mV (η = 138 mV) at 10 mA/cm
2
with a Tafel slope of 48 mV/dec. The role of P boosted the HER catalytic performance of Cu and Co because of the chemical shifting of metal–P bonds, indicating that the electronegativity had a determinative effect on the catalytic performance of Cu–Co–P foams, significantly decreasing the HER overpotential. The Cu–Co–P
20
foam had the largest ECSA of 85 cm
2
and a higher areal proportion of pores than electrodes formed with other compositions. In addition, this study not only provides a new method for the synthesis of Cu–Co–P electrocatalyst based on the electrodeposition method that can secure physical bonding at the powder electrode, but also it can be developed as an anode electrode in AEM water electrolysis system with a high efficiency.

Hosseini, Seyed Ehsan; Abdul Wahid, Mazlan

Fossil fuel consumption in transportation system and energy-intensive sectors as the principal pillar of civilization is assocd. with progressive release of greenhouse gases. Hydrogen as a promising energy carrier is a perfect candidate to supply the energy demand of the world and concomitantly reduce toxic emissions. This article gives an overview of the state-of-the-art hydrogen prodn. technologies using renewable and sustainable energy resources. Hydrogen from supercrit. water gasification (SCWG) of biomass is the most cost effective thermochem. process. Highly moisturized biomass is utilized directly in SCWG without any high cost drying process. In SCWG, hydrogen is produced at high pressure and small amt. of energy is required to pressurize hydrogen in the storage tank. Tar and char formation decreases drastically in biomass SCWG. The low efficiency of solar to hydrogen system as well as expensive photovoltaic cell are the most important barriers for the widespread com. development of solar-based hydrogen prodn. Since electricity costs play a crucial role on the final hydrogen price, to generate carbon free hydrogen from solar and wind energy at a competitive price with fossil fuels, the elec. energy cost should be four times less than com. electricity prices.

MoS2 Nanoparticles Grown on Graphene: An Advanced Catalyst for the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction
Li, Yanguang; Wang, Hailiang; Xie, Liming; Liang, Yongye; Hong, Guosong; Dai, Hongjie

Advanced materials for electrocatalytic and photoelectrochem. H2O splitting are central to the area of renewable energy. The authors developed a selective solvothermal synthesis of MoS2 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) sheets suspended in soln. The resulting MoS2/RGO hybrid material possessed nanoscopic few-layer MoS2 structures with an abundance of exposed edges stacked onto graphene, in strong contrast to large aggregated MoS2 particles grown freely in soln. without GO. The MoS2/RGO hybrid exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity in the H evolution reaction (HER) relative to other MoS2 catalysts. A Tafel slope of ∼41 mV/decade was measured for MoS2 catalysts in the HER for the 1st time; this exceeds by far the activity of previous MoS2 catalysts and results from the abundance of catalytic edge sites on the MoS2 nanoparticles and the excellent elec. coupling to the underlying graphene network. The ∼41 mV/decade Tafel slope suggested the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism for the MoS2-catalyzed HER, with electrochem. desorption of H as the rate-limiting step.

Gong, Ming; Zhou, Wu; Tsai, Mon-Che; Zhou, Jigang; Guan, Mingyun; Lin, Meng-Chang; Zhang, Bo; Hu, Yongfeng; Wang, Di-Yan; Yang, Jiang; Pennycook, Stephen J.; Hwang, Bing-Joe; Dai, Hongjie

Active, stable and cost-effective electrocatalysts are a key to water splitting for hydrogen prodn. through electrolysis or photoelectrochem. Here we report nanoscale nickel oxide/nickel heterostructures formed on carbon nanotube sidewalls as highly effective electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction with activity similar to platinum. Partially reduced nickel interfaced with nickel oxide results from thermal decompn. of nickel hydroxide precursors bonded to carbon nanotube sidewalls. The metal ion-carbon nanotube interactions impede complete redn. and Ostwald ripening of nickel species into the less hydrogen evolution reaction active pure nickel phase. A water electrolyzer that achieves ∼20 mA cm-2 at a voltage of 1.5 V, and which may be operated by a single-cell alk. battery, is fabricated using cheap, non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts.

McCrory, Charles C. L.; Jung, Suho; Ferrer, Ivonne M.; Chatman, Shawn M.; Peters, Jonas C.; Jaramillo, Thomas F.

Objective comparisons of electrocatalyst activity and stability using std. methods under identical conditions are necessary to evaluate the viability of existing electrocatalysts for integration into solar-fuel devices as well as to help inform the development of new catalytic systems. Herein, the authors use a std. protocol as a primary screen for evaluating the activity, short-term (2 h) stability, and electrochem. active surface area (ECSA) of 18 electrocatalysts for the H evolution reaction (HER) and 26 electrocatalysts for the O evolution reaction (OER) under conditions relevant to an integrated solar H2O-splitting device in aq. acidic or alk. soln. The primary figure of merit is the overpotential necessary to achieve a magnitude c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 per geometric area, the approx. c.d. expected for a 10% efficient solar-to-fuels conversion device under 1 sun illumination. The specific activity per ECSA of each material is also reported. Among HER catalysts, several could operate at 10 mA cm-2 with overpotentials <0.1 V in acidic and/or alk. solns. Among OER catalysts in acidic soln., no nonnoble metal based materials showed promising activity and stability, whereas in alk. soln. many OER catalysts performed with similar activity achieving 10 mA cm-2 current densities at overpotentials of ∼0.33-0.5 V. Most OER catalysts showed comparable or better specific activity per ECSA when compared to Ir and Ru catalysts in alk. solns., while most HER catalysts showed much lower specific activity than Pt in both acidic and alk. solns. For select catalysts, addnl. secondary screening measurements were conducted including faradaic efficiency and extended stability measurements.

With mesoporous structure introduced by ZnCl2 salt and cathodic activation, it demonstrates an onset overpotential as low as 76 mV, a Tafel slope of 58.4 mV dec-1, and a large normalized exchange c.d. of 1.72 × 10-2 mA cm-2, which are comparable to those of hitherto best metal-free and well-fabricated metallic HER catalysts.

The urgent need of clean and renewable energy drives the exploration of effective strategies to produce mol. hydrogen. With the assistance of highly active non-noble metal electrocatalysts, electrolysis of water is becoming a promising candidate to generate pure hydrogen with low cost and high efficiency. Very recently, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been proven to be high performance catalysts with high activity, high stability, and nearly ∼100% Faradic efficiency in not only strong acidic solns., but also in strong alk. and neutral media for electrochem. hydrogen evolution. In this tutorial review, an overview of recent development of TMP nanomaterials as catalysts for hydrogen generation with high activity and stability is presented. The effects of phosphorus (P) on HER activity, and their synthetic methods of TMPs are briefly discussed. Then we will demonstrate the specific strategies to further improve the catalytic efficiency and stability of TMPs by structural engineering. Making use of TMPs as cocatalysts and catalysts in photochem. and photoelectrochem. water splitting is also discussed. Finally, some key challenges and issues which should not be ignored during the rapid development of TMPs are pointed out. These strategies and challenges of TMPs are instructive for designing other high-performance non-noble metal catalysts.

The efficiency and stability of electrocatalysts are the key factors influencing the process of overall water splitting. In the research reported in this paper, the universal two-step method of co-pptn. and sulfuration is used to directly grow hierarchical nickel(II) hydroxide/trinickel disulfide [Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2] hybrid on nickel foam. The results show that the Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h material used as the three-dimensional (3D) substrate electrode can maximize the synergy between the Ni(OH)2 and Ni3S2, and it also exhibits high efficiency and persistent stability of the oxygen evolution reaction. The lower overpotential of only 270 mV at 20 mA cm-2 compared to the benchmark of iridium(IV) oxide electrodes (300 mV of overpotential at 20 mA cm-2) benefited from the particular hybrid structure of Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h with large voids and vol. and rapid charge transfer. In addn., the Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h material also shows a remarkable improved hydrogen evolution reaction activity compared to that of Ni(OH)2, Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-9h and Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-15h individual catalysts, with which a low overpotential of only 211 mV is achieved at 20 mA cm-2. Remarkably, Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h is used as a bifunctional water splitting catalyst, with which an overpotential of ∼340 mV is acquired at a very low cell voltage of 1.57 V with 10 mA cm-2 in 1.0 M potassium hydroxide. These results demonstrate that most hydroxide/sulfide-based materials can be used as a electrocatalyst candidate and provide a superior synergy strategy, which provides a new way for robust water splitting electrochem. fabrication of high-performance and inexpensive electrode materials.

Transition metal phosphides recently have been identified as promising Earth-abundant electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Here, a general and scalable strategy is presented for the synthesis of transition metal phosphide electrodes based on the reaction of com. available metal foils (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and NiFe) with various organophosphine reagents. The resulting phosphide electrodes were found to exhibit excellent electrocatalytic HER and OER performance. The most active electrodes required overpotentials of only -128 mV for the HER in acid (Ni2P), -183 mV for the HER in base (Ni2P), and 277 mV for the OER in base (NiFeP) to produce operationally relevant current densities of 10 mA cm-2. Such HER and OER performance compares favorably with samples prepd. using significantly more elaborate and costly procedures. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that the approach can also be utilized to obtain highly active and conformal metal phosphide coatings on photocathode materials, such as highly doped Si, that are relevant to solar fuels prodn.

Hydrogen is essential to many industrial processes and could play an important role as an ideal clean energy carrier for future energy supply. Herein, we report for the first time the growth of cryst. Cu3P phosphide nanosheets on conductive nickel foam (
[email protected]
) for electrocatalytic and visible light-driven overall water splitting. Our results show that the
[email protected]
electrode can be used as an efficient Janus catalyst for both the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). For OER catalysis, a c.d. of 10 mA/cm2 requires an overpotential of only ∼320 mV and the slope of the Tafel plot is as low as 54 mV/dec in 1.0 M KOH. For HER catalysis, the overpotential is only ∼105 mV to achieve a catalytic c.d. of 10 mA cm-2. Moreover, overall water splitting can be achieved in a water electrolyzer based on the
[email protected]
electrode, which showed a catalytic c.d. of 10 mA/cm2 under an applied voltage of ∼1.67 V. The same c.d. can also be obtained using a silicon solar cell under ∼1.70 V for both the HER and the OER. This new Janus
[email protected]
electrode is made of inexpensive and nonprecious metal-based materials, which opens new possibilities based on copper to exploit overall water splitting for hydrogen prodn. To the best of our knowledge, such high performance of a copper-based water oxidn. and overall water splitting catalyst has not been reported to date.

Searching for inexpensive hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalysts with high activity has attracted considerable research interest in the past years. Reported herein is the topotactic fabrication of self-supported Cu3P nanowire arrays on com. porous copper foam (Cu3P NW/CF) from its Cu(OH)2 NW/CF precursor by a low-temp. phosphidation reaction. Remarkably, as an integrated three-dimensional hydrogen-evolving cathode operating in acidic electrolytes, Cu3P NW/CF maintains its activity for at least 25 h and exhibits an onset overpotential of 62 mV, a Tafel slope of 67 mV dec-1, and a Faradaic efficiency close to 100 %. Catalytic c.d. can approach 10 mA cm-2 at an overpotential of 143 mV.

Although electrocatalysts based on transition metal phosphides (TMPs) with cationic/anionic doping have been widely studied for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the origin of performance enhancement still remains elusive mainly due to the random dispersion of dopants. D. functional theory calcns. and exptl. results reveal that the electron transfer from CoP to Co-MOF through N-P/N-Co bonds could lead to the optimized adsorption energy of H2O (ΔGH2O*) and hydrogen (ΔGH*), which, together with the unique porous structure of Co-MOF, contributes to the remarkable HER performance with an overpotential of 49 mV at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 in 1 M phosphate buffer soln. In addn., the CoP/Co-MOF hybrid also displays Pt-like performance in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, with the overpotentials of 27 and 34 mV, resp., at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2.

Finding new methods to design environmentally friendly, highly stable, and robust oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts remains an extremely important challenge and affords several opportunities for exploiting the water-splitting process. In our work, Cu-Co-M (M = O, S, P, Se, S-P, and P-S) materials were grown in situ on three-dimensional (3D) porous nickel foam (NF) with good elec. cond. by hydrothermal synthesis, vulcanization, selenylation, and phosphorization of the Cu-Co-precursor under an Ar atm. Cu-Co-P-S/NF presents an overpotential value of 220 mV at 50 mA cm-2 for OER and that for Cu-Co-P-S/NF of 120 mV at 10 mA cm-2 for HER in an alk. medium. In addn., considering the superior activities of Cu-Co-P-S/NF for OER and HER, the electrode pairing of Cu-Co-P-SOER//Cu-Co-P-SHER is designed for overall water splitting, and the exptl. result shows that only a cell voltage of 1.55 V is needed to obtain a c.d. of 20 mA cm-2. According to the literature, this cell voltage is also among the lowest values that have been previously reported for electrocatalytic water splitting. Further, Cu-Co-P-S//Cu-Co-P-S exhibited efficient stability during a 20 h durability test without significant attenuation under alk. conditions. By using XPS spectroscopy characterization, it was shown that Cu-Co-P-S presented the highest catalytic performance and long-term durability owing to the abundance of Co3+. The novelty of selecting the highest activity with the same catalyst for OER and HER from Cu-Co-M (M = O, S, P, Se, S-P, and P-S) in order to obtain a well-matched electrode pair, and therefore, simplifying the water-splitting device affords a wide range of possibilities for further exploitation of environmentally friendly and highly efficient electrode pairs.

Electrochem. water splitting into hydrogen and oxygen is a promising method for solar energy storage. The development of efficient electrocatalysts for water splitting has drawn much attention. However, catalysts that are active for both the hydrogen evolution and oxygen evolution reactions are rare. Herein, we show for the first time that nickel phosphide (Ni2P), an excellent hydrogen evolving catalyst, is also highly active for oxygen evolution. A c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 is generated at an overpotential of only 290 mV in 1 M KOH. The high activity is attributed to the core-shell (Ni2P/NiOx) structure that the material adopts under catalytic conditions. The Ni2P nanoparticles can serve as both cathode and anode catalysts for an alk. electrolyzer, which generates 10 mA cm-2 at 1.63 V.

The Ni phosphide (Ni2P) family of materials have become a hot subject in H evolution reaction (HER) electrocatalyst research. Various studies have reported their high activity, high stability, and high faradaic efficiency. To date, there have been no systematic studies regarding the influence of pH on the HER performance of Ni2P. The pH of electrolytes can strongly influence the HER activity of Ni2P electrocatalysts. Tests in 19 electrolytes with pH ranging from 0.52 to 13.53 show that Ni2P is much more active in strongly acidic and basic electrolytes. With the increase of pH, the lower H+ concn. reduces the formation of adsorbed H atoms in the Volmer reaction, resulting in poorer activities. However, the high activity obsd. in the strongly basic electrolytes is not the intrinsic property of Ni2P. Ni oxides/hydroxides are formed in strongly basic electrolytes under applied potentials, resulting in improved activities. Also, the specific activity based on the electrochem. active surface area of recently reported Ni2P catalysts is not high and requires significant improvements for practical applications.

Herein, we report a simplistic method to fabricate the surface-oxidized cobalt phosphide (CoP) nanocrystals (NCs), which is used as electrocatalyst for oxygen redn. reaction (ORR) in microbial fuel cell (MFC) for the first time. The corallite-like CoP NCs are successfully prepd. by a hydrothermal reaction following a phosphating treatment in N2 atmosphere. When used as an ORR catalyst, cobalt phosphide shows comparable onset potential, inferior resistance, as well as a small Tafel slope with long-term stability in neutral media. The max. power d. of MFC embellished with 10% CoP reached 1914.4 ± 59.7 mW m-2, which is 108.5% higher than the control. In addn., material characterizations indicate that the surface oxide layer (CoOx) around the metallic CoP core is important and beneficial for ORR. Accordingly, it can be expected that the as-synthesized CoP will be a promising candidate of the non-precious metal ORR electrocatalysts for electrochem. energy applications.

Low temp. fuel cells are clean, effective alternative fuel conversion technol. O redn. reaction (ORR) at the fuel cell cathode has required Pt as the electrocatalyst for high activity and selectivity of the 4-electron reaction pathway. Targeting a less expensive, earth abundant alternative, the authors have developed the synthesis of Co phosphide (Co2P) nanorods for ORR. Characterization techniques that include total x-ray scattering and extended X-ray absorption fine structure revealed a deviation of the nanorods from bulk crystal structure with a contraction along the b orthorhombic lattice parameter. The C supported nanorods have comparable activity but are remarkably more stable than conventional Pt catalysts for the O redn. reaction in alk. environments.

Designing efficient, stable and inexpensive electrocatalysts to replace Pt-based catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is highly desired in renewable energy research. In this study, we report the synthesis of nickel phosphide nanoparticles decorated on multiwalled carbon nanotubes (Ni2P/CNT) by in situ thermal decompn. of nickel acetylacetonate as a nickel source and trioctylphosphine as a phosphorus source in oleylamine soln. of CNT. In addn., the Ni2P/CNT nanohybrid shows nearly 100% Faradaic efficiency in acid solns. This work successfully demonstrates that the introduction of Ni2P NPs into CNT for enhanced electrocatalytic properties is feasible, and that this may open up a potential way for designing more efficient Ni2P-based catalysts for the HER.

A highly efficient porous NiCu-phosphide (NiCu-P) electrode is reported for a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in acidic, neutral, and basic electrolytes. The NiCu-P electrode was prepd. via hydrogen bubbles dynamic templated electrodeposition of NiCu alloy onto nickel mesh, followed by phosphidation. Due to the synergistic interaction in NiCu-P, the material exhibits excellent HER activity in a wide pH range from 0.3-14. The influence of the PTFE content in com. Toray graphite paper gas diffusion layer (GDL) on the performance of a PBI-based polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) has been studied. These materials have been characterized by evaluating the porosity, pore size distribution, SEM micrographs, hydrophobicity, air permeability and elec. resistance. Fuel cell results show that the lower the Teflon content, the better the cell performance and the lower the losses when oxygen was replaced by air. These results led to non-Teflonized carbon paper to be postulated as the most suitable candidate, provided that its mech. integrity can be maintained throughout the whole process of prepn. and testing of the MEA. However, some practical problems with this type of com. non-Teflonized carbon paper were experienced in this work and led to damage of the support. The detrimental effects are described and discussed. As conclusion, the use of a minimally PTFE-loaded (10%) carbon paper is suggested because the inclusion of this level of Teflon improved properly the mech. properties of the carbon support and only caused a very small drop in the performance.

The effect of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) content on morphol. characteristics of carbon/PTFE films deposited on porous carbon support was investigated by mercury-porosimetry, SEM and a.c. impedance spectroscopy. The presence of cracks, increasing in no. and size with PTFE content, was also revealed.

Nanoporous metallic electrodes were prepd. by electrodeposition. The technique involves electroeposition with hydrogen evolution. The hydrogen bubbles function as a dynamic neg. template and play a crucial role in the formation of the porous structure. The resulting structures are 3D free-standing foams of metals such as Cu and Sn with highly porous ramified (dendritic) walls. The porous structures are ideally suited for electrodes in electrochem. devices such as fuel cells, batteries, and chem. sensors. In particular, the porous Sn deposits are being directly used as 3D nanoporous anode for Li batteries and the nanoporous Cu deposits are being used for construction of nanocomposite anodes for solid oxide fuel cells. Further, the nanoporous Cu deposits can be used as 3D templates for prepn. of porous structures of other functional materials, including electrodes for solid oxide fuel cells and solid-state gas sensors.

A variety of copper foams with highly open porous walls were successfully sculptured using the gas evolved in an electrochem. deposition process. The pore sizes and wall structures of the foams are tunable by adjusting the deposition conditions. Despite tremendous efforts in the synthesis of various porous carbon materials, the effect of carbon materials on cell capacity remains unclear. Based on the study of eight different carbon electrode materials with various pore sizes and pore vols. in Li-O2 batteries, it was found that the initial discharge capacity was hardly affected by the surface area or pore vol. Instead, it was directly correlated with the pore sizes. To further verify this finding, meso- and macro-porous carbon materials with pore sizes in the range of 20-100 nm were prepd. using spherical silica as a template. The results clearly showed that the cell capacity increases with the increase of pore size and eventually reached its max. at 7169 mA h g-1 at a pore size of 80 nm. A phys. model proposed to illustrate the effect of carbon pore size on cell capacity is the formation of a monolayer of Li2O2 with a thickness of 7.8 nm inside the carbon pores during the discharge process which limits the diffusion of incoming oxygen at smaller pore size (< 80 nm).

The authors study the morphol. of Cu films electrodeposited onto Si from an acidic sulfate electrolyte with the addn. of a variable concn. of chloride anions. Addn. of chloride increases grain size and the degree of grain faceting while decreasing the d. of growth nuclei. Well-developed monocryst. dendrites are formed in acidic sulfate solns. with high concn. of chloride. Dendrites form under growth conditions that either approach diffusion limitation, or occur within a potential range where different crystallog. faces exhibit a different potential dependence for chloride desorption. The presence of dendrites however is mainly related to the fact that the redn. route Cu2+ → CuCl → Cu becomes the rate-detg. process in solns. with high chloride concn.; the rate of this reaction is largest at {110} planes, where the concn. of chloride anions is the highest, generating dendrites with branches along the {110} directions.

Use of Platinum as the Counter Electrode to Study the Activity of Nonprecious Metal Catalysts for the Hydrogen Evolution Reaction
Chen, Rong; Yang, Cangjie; Cai, Weizheng; Wang, Hsin-Yi; Miao, Jianwei; Zhang, Liping; Chen, Shengli; Liu, Bin

In conclusion, we carefully studied the dissoln. behavior of Pt as the counter electrode during the electrochem. measurement of HER activity. Our results show that both electrochem. and chem. dissoln. of Pt in acidic or alk. electrolyte cause redeposition of Pt on the working electrode of interest, which significantly improves the HER activity. As a result, Pt should not be selected as the counter electrode for measuring the activity of HER unless it is coupled with an ion-exchange membrane, which was commonly ignored during past research. Addnl., Pt is also susceptible to sulfur compds. (e.g., sulfide), nitrogen compds. (e.g.,cyanide), and CO, leading to Pt poisoning due to strong chemisorption. Therefore, electrolyte purifn. to remove those poisonous impurities is necessary if Pt is chosen as the counter electrode. Considering how to choose the right counter electrode for electrochem. measurements, we provide the following suggestions: first, the counter electrode must be both chem. and electrochem. stable, for example, glassy carbon or graphite for the oxidn. reaction(counter electrode for HER or ORR) and Pt for the redn. reaction (counter electrode for OER, a small amt. of Pt dissoln. will not affect OER performance because Pt is prone to redeposit onto the cathode). Second, the half-reaction occurring at the counter electrode should be fast enough to enable the reaction at the working electrode. Regarding this point, alternative strategies can be adopted. One approach is to choose a counter electrode with high catalytic activity, and another is to render the counter electrode with a larger surface area than that of the working electrode to make up the large energetic barrier. Our work provides a complete understanding of the Pt counter electrode effect during HER characterization and should arouse awareness of the results in those recently published papers.

Objective evaluation of the activity of electrocatalysts for water oxidn. is of fundamental importance for the development of promising energy conversion technologies including integrated solar water-splitting devices, water electrolyzers, and Li-air batteries. However, current methods employed to evaluate oxygen-evolving catalysts are not standardized, making it difficult to compare the activity and stability of these materials. We report a protocol for evaluating the activity, stability, and Faradaic efficiency of electrodeposited oxygen-evolving electrocatalysts. In particular, we focus on methods for detg. electrochem. active surface area and measuring electrocatalytic activity and stability under conditions relevant to an integrated solar water-splitting device. Our primary figure of merit is the overpotential required to achieve a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 per geometric area, approx. the c.d. expected for a 10% efficient solar-to-fuels conversion device. Utilizing the aforementioned surface area measurements, one can det. electrocatalyst turnover frequencies. The reported protocol was used to examine the oxygen-evolution activity of the following systems in acidic and alk. solns.: CoOx, CoPi, CoFeOx, NiOx, NiCeOx, NiCoOx, NiCuOx, NiFeOx, and NiLaOx. The oxygen-evolving activity of an electrodeposited IrOx catalyst was also investigated for comparison. Two general observations are made from comparing the catalytic performance of the OER catalysts investigated: (1) in alk. soln., every non-noble metal system achieved 10 mA cm-2 current densities at similar operating overpotentials between 0.35 and 0.43 V, and (2) every system but IrOx was unstable under oxidative conditions in acidic solns.

The structural evolution and diffusion during the chemical transformation from cobalt to cobalt phosphide nanoparticles

We report the structural evolution and the diffusion processes which occur during the phase transformation of nanoparticles (NPs), .vepsiln.-Co to Co2P to CoP, from a reaction with tri-n-octylphosphine (TOP). Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) investigations were used to elucidate the changes in the local structure of cobalt atoms which occur as the chem. transformation progresses. The lack of long-range order, spread in interat. distances, and overall increase in mean-square disorder compared with bulk structure reveal the decrease in the NP's structural order compared with bulk structure, which contributes to their deviation from bulk-like behavior. Results from EXAFS show both the Co2P and CoP phases contain excess Co. Results from EXAFS, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and d. functional theory calcns. reveal that the inward diffusion of phosphorus is more favorable at the beginning of the transformation from .vepsiln.-Co to Co2P by forming an amorphous Co-P shell, while retaining a cryst. cobalt core. When the major phase of the sample turns to Co2P, the diffusion processes reverse and cobalt atom out-diffusion is favored, leaving a hollow void, characteristic of the nanoscale Kirkendall effect. For the transformation from Co2P to CoP theory predicts an outward diffusion of cobalt while the anion lattice remains intact. In real samples, however, the Co-rich nanoparticles continue Kirkendall hollowing. Knowledge about the transformation method and structural properties provides a means to tailor the synthesis and compn. of the NPs to facilitate their use in applications.

Developing earth abundant catalysts for clean energy technologies is vital to address the issues related to the use of fossil fuels and assocd. pollution, which adversely affects human health. Herein, the authors report an electrochem. deposited mixed Cu-Co-P film, as a bifunctional catalyst with high stability and activity for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, in 0.5M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER, in 1 M KOH). In alk. medium, the Cu-Co-P catalyst outperforms the state-of-art catalysts for both HER (Pt) and OER (RuO2) and is stable under continuous electrolysis for up to 72 h. Using Cu-Co-P electrodes as both the anode and the cathode increase the activity (1.80 V to reach 10 mA/cm2 c.d.) by ∼2.5 times greater than the integrated performance of RuO2 (anode) and Pt black (cathode) at 1.9 V (1.87 V to reach 10 mA/cm2 c.d.). The competent bi-functionality of Cu-Co-P is facilitated by Cu incorporation, leading to a low surface passivation of the electrode. This study offers a new strategy to develop earth abundant bimetallic phosphides, which are potential catalysts for many alternative energy technologies.

Two-phase Cu-Ni magnetic metallic foams (MMFs) with tunable compn. have been prepd. by electrodeposition taking advantage of hydrogen co-evolution as a source of porosity. It is obsd. that Ni tends to deposit inside the porous network defined by the Cu building blocks. Contact angle measurements reveal that the prepd. porous films show a remarkable superhydrophobicity (contact angle values larger than 150°) and a non-sticking property to aq. droplets. This behavior is predominately ascribed to the morphol. of the films - hierarchical micro/nanoporosity, wall thickness, and spatial arrangement. The electrochem. activity and stability towards hydrogen evolution reaction of the Cu-Ni MMFs has been investigated by cyclic voltammetry in 1 M KOH at 298 K, and the optimal Ni content is found to be 15 at%. Furthermore, all the foam-like films exhibit ferromagnetic behavior due to the presence of the Ni-rich phase, with coercivity values ranging from 114 Oe to 300 Oe. From the technol. point of view, the Cu-Ni MMFs are promising candidates for magnetically-actuated micro/nano-electromech. systems (MEMS/NEMS) and micro/nanorobotic platforms with a large surface-area to vol. ratio or in magnetic sensors or separators.

Zhang, Yue; Gao, Lu; Hensen, Emiel J. M.; Hofmann, Jan P.
ACS Energy Letters
(
2018
),
3
(
6
),
1360-1365
CODEN:
AELCCP
; ISSN:
2380-8195
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
The evaluation of the stability of emerging earth-abundant metal phosphide electrocatalysts by solely electrochem. current-potential sweeps is often not conclusive. In this study, the Co2P is investigated to evaluate its stability under both acidic (0.5 M H2SO4) and alk. (1.0 M KOH) hydrogen evolution (HER) conditions. It was found that the electrochem. surface area (ECSA) of Co2P only slightly increased in acidic conditions but almost doubled after electrolysis in alk. electrolyte. The surface compn. of the electrode remained almost unchanged in acid but was significantly altered in alk. during current-potential sweeps. Anal. of the electrolytes after the stability test shows almost stoichiometric compn. of Co and P in acid, but a preferential dissoln. of P over Co could be obsd. in alk. electrolyte. Applying comprehensive postcatalysis anal. of both the electrode and electrolyte, we conclude that Co2P, prepd. by thermal phosphidization, dissolves stoichiometrically in acid and degrades to hydroxides under alk. stability testing.

Stacked Porous Iron-Doped Nickel Cobalt Phosphide Nanoparticle: An Efficient and Stable Water Splitting Electrocatalyst
Ray, Chaiti; Lee, Su Chan; Jin, Bingjun; Kundu, Aniruddha; Park, Jong Hyeok; Jun, Seong Chan
ACS Sustainable Chemistry & Engineering

2018
),

(

2168-0485
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Exploration of proficient electrocatalyst from earth-abundant nonprecious metals in lieu of noble metal-based catalysts to obtain clean hydrogen energy through large-scale electrochem. water splitting is still an ongoing challenge. Herein, iron-doped nickel cobalt phosphide nanoplate arrays grown on a carbon cloth (NiCoFexP/CC) are fabricated using a simple hydrothermal route, followed by phosphorization. The electrochem. anal. demonstrates that the NiCoFexP/CC electrode possesses high electrocatalytic activity for water splitting in alk. medium. Benefits from the synergistic effect between the metal centers, two-dimensional porous nanoplates, and unique three-dimensional electrode configuration of NiCoFexP/CC provide small overpotentials of 39 at 10 mA cm-2 and 275 mV at 50 mA cm-2 to drive the hydrogen evolution reaction and oxygen evolution reaction, resp. Furthermore, the assembled two-electrode (NiCoFexP/CC‖NiCoFexP/CC) alk. water electrolyzer can achieve 10 mA cm-2 c.d. at 1.51 V. Remarkably, it can maintain stable electrolysis over 150 h. The excellent activity and stability of this catalyst is proved to be a economical substitute of com. noble metal-based catalysts in technologies relevant to renewable energy.

CoP for hydrogen evolution: implications from hydrogen adsorption
Hu, Guoxiang; Tang, Qing; Jiang, De-en

CODEN:

.

Royal Society of Chemistry

Cobalt phosphide (CoP) is one of the most promising, earth-abundant electrocatalysts discovered to date for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), yet the mechanism is not well understood. Since hydrogen adsorption is a key factor of HER activity, here the adsorption ie examd. of at. hydrogen on the low-Miller-index surfaces of CoP, including (111), (110), (100), and (011), by using periodic d. functional theory. From the calcd. Gibbs free energy of adsorption, it is predicted that (111), (110), and (011) surfaces will have good catalytic activities for HER. From ab initio atomistic thermodn., it is found that the stabilities of the surfaces at 1 atm H2 and 300 K follow the trend of (111) > (100) ∼ (110) » (011). On the most stable (111) surface, both Co bridge sites and P top sites are found to be able to adsorb hydrogen with a close-to-zero free energy change and the synergy of proximal Co and P atoms on the surface results in a better HER activity. The work provides important insights into CoP's excellent HER activity and a basis for further mechanistic understanding of HER on CoP and other transition-metal phosphides.

Catalysts for Hydrogen Evolution from the [NiFe] Hydrogenase to the Ni2P(001) Surface: The Importance of Ensemble Effect
Liu, Ping; Rodriguez, Jose A.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2005
),

(

CODEN:
JACSAT
; ISSN:

.
(
American Chemical Society
)
D. functional theory (DFT) was employed to investigate the behavior of a series of catalysts used in the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER, 2H+ + 2e- → H2). The kinetics of the HER was studied on the [NiFe] hydrogenase, the [Ni(PS3*)(CO)]1- and [Ni(PNP)2]2+ complexes, and surfaces such as Ni(111), Pt(111), or Ni2P(001). Our results show that the [NiFe] hydrogenase exhibits the highest activity toward the HER, followed by [Ni(PNP)2]2+ > Ni2P > [Ni(PS3*)(CO)]1- > Pt > Ni in a decreasing sequence. The slow kinetics of the HER on the surfaces is due to the fact that the metal hollow sites bond hydrogen too strongly to allow the facile removal of H2. In fact, the strong H-Ni interaction on Ni2P(001) can lead to poisoning of the highly active sites of the surface, which enhances the rate of the HER and makes it comparable to that of the [NiFe] hydrogenase. In contrast, the promotional effect of H-poisoning on the HER on Pt and Ni surfaces is relatively small. Our calcns. suggest that among all of the systems investigated, Ni2P should be the best practical catalyst for the HER, combining the high thermostability of the surfaces and high catalytic activity of the [NiFe] hydrogenase. The good behavior of Ni2P(001) toward the HER is found to be assocd. with an ensemble effect, where the no. of active Ni sites is decreased due to presence of P, which leads to moderate bonding of the intermediates and products with the surface. In addn., the P sites are not simple spectators and directly participate in the HER.

Electrochem. prodn. of hydrogen from water has been directed to the search for non-noble metal based and earth-abundant catalysts. In this work, we propose a novel cost-effective catalyst, molybdenum phosphide that exhibits high activity towards the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) in both acid and alk. media even in bulk form. Comparative anal. of Mo, Mo3P and MoP as catalysts for HER clearly indicates that phosphorization can potentially modify the properties of the metal and different degrees of phosphorization lead to distinct activities and stabilities. Theor. calcns. by d. functional theory also show that a simple phosphorization of molybdenum to form MoP introduces a good 'H delivery' system which attains nearly zero binding to H at a certain H coverage. With the combination of exptl. results and theor. calcns., this work has enlightened a new way of exploring cost-effective catalysts for HER.

The identification of the active sites in heterogeneous catalysis requires a combination of surface sensitive methods and reactivity studies. The authors detd. the active site for hydrogen evolution, a reaction catalyzed by precious metals, on nanoparticulate Mo disulfide (MoS2) by atomically resolving the surface of this catalyst before measuring electrochem. activity in soln. By prepg. MoS2 nanoparticles of different sizes, the authors systematically varied the distribution of surface sites on MoS2 nanoparticles on Au(111), which the authors quantified with scanning tunneling microscopy. Electrocatalytic activity measurements for hydrogen evolution correlate linearly with the no. of edge sites on the MoS2 catalyst.

Hydrophilic cobalt sulfide nanosheets as a bifunctional catalyst for oxygen and hydrogen evolution in electrolysis of alkaline aqueous solution
Zhu, Mingchao; Zhang, Zhongyi; Zhang, Hu; Zhang, Hui; Zhang, Xiaodong; Zhang, Lixue; Wang, Shicai

A hydrophilic medium and precursor compds. were used to prep. a hydrophilic electro-catalyst for water splitting. This cobalt sulfide (Co3S4) catalyst had a layered nanosheet structure with a hydrophilic surface, which facilitated the diffusion of aq. substrates into electrode pores and toward active sites. The Co3S4 catalyst displayed excellent bifunctional catalytic activity for the oxygen and hydrogen evolution reactions (OER, HER) in alk. soln. An assembled water electrolyzer based on Co3S4 exhibited better performance and stability than one with a Pt/C-RuO2 catalyst. Hence, hydrophilic Co3S4 is a highly promising bifunctional catalyst for the water splitting reaction.

Fossil fuel consumption in transportation system and energy-intensive sectors as the principal pillar of civilization is assocd. with progressive release of greenhouse gases. Hydrogen as a promising energy carrier is a perfect candidate to supply the energy demand of the world and concomitantly reduce toxic emissions. This article gives an overview of the state-of-the-art hydrogen prodn. technologies using renewable and sustainable energy resources. Hydrogen from supercrit. water gasification (SCWG) of biomass is the most cost effective thermochem. process. Highly moisturized biomass is utilized directly in SCWG without any high cost drying process. In SCWG, hydrogen is produced at high pressure and small amt. of energy is required to pressurize hydrogen in the storage tank. Tar and char formation decreases drastically in biomass SCWG. The low efficiency of solar to hydrogen system as well as expensive photovoltaic cell are the most important barriers for the widespread com. development of solar-based hydrogen prodn. Since electricity costs play a crucial role on the final hydrogen price, to generate carbon free hydrogen from solar and wind energy at a competitive price with fossil fuels, the elec. energy cost should be four times less than com. electricity prices.

Advanced materials for electrocatalytic and photoelectrochem. H2O splitting are central to the area of renewable energy. The authors developed a selective solvothermal synthesis of MoS2 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide (RGO) sheets suspended in soln. The resulting MoS2/RGO hybrid material possessed nanoscopic few-layer MoS2 structures with an abundance of exposed edges stacked onto graphene, in strong contrast to large aggregated MoS2 particles grown freely in soln. without GO. The MoS2/RGO hybrid exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity in the H evolution reaction (HER) relative to other MoS2 catalysts. A Tafel slope of ∼41 mV/decade was measured for MoS2 catalysts in the HER for the 1st time; this exceeds by far the activity of previous MoS2 catalysts and results from the abundance of catalytic edge sites on the MoS2 nanoparticles and the excellent elec. coupling to the underlying graphene network. The ∼41 mV/decade Tafel slope suggested the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism for the MoS2-catalyzed HER, with electrochem. desorption of H as the rate-limiting step.

Active, stable and cost-effective electrocatalysts are a key to water splitting for hydrogen prodn. through electrolysis or photoelectrochem. Here we report nanoscale nickel oxide/nickel heterostructures formed on carbon nanotube sidewalls as highly effective electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction with activity similar to platinum. Partially reduced nickel interfaced with nickel oxide results from thermal decompn. of nickel hydroxide precursors bonded to carbon nanotube sidewalls. The metal ion-carbon nanotube interactions impede complete redn. and Ostwald ripening of nickel species into the less hydrogen evolution reaction active pure nickel phase. A water electrolyzer that achieves ∼20 mA cm-2 at a voltage of 1.5 V, and which may be operated by a single-cell alk. battery, is fabricated using cheap, non-precious metal-based electrocatalysts.

Objective comparisons of electrocatalyst activity and stability using std. methods under identical conditions are necessary to evaluate the viability of existing electrocatalysts for integration into solar-fuel devices as well as to help inform the development of new catalytic systems. Herein, the authors use a std. protocol as a primary screen for evaluating the activity, short-term (2 h) stability, and electrochem. active surface area (ECSA) of 18 electrocatalysts for the H evolution reaction (HER) and 26 electrocatalysts for the O evolution reaction (OER) under conditions relevant to an integrated solar H2O-splitting device in aq. acidic or alk. soln. The primary figure of merit is the overpotential necessary to achieve a magnitude c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 per geometric area, the approx. c.d. expected for a 10% efficient solar-to-fuels conversion device under 1 sun illumination. The specific activity per ECSA of each material is also reported. Among HER catalysts, several could operate at 10 mA cm-2 with overpotentials <0.1 V in acidic and/or alk. solns. Among OER catalysts in acidic soln., no nonnoble metal based materials showed promising activity and stability, whereas in alk. soln. many OER catalysts performed with similar activity achieving 10 mA cm-2 current densities at overpotentials of ∼0.33-0.5 V. Most OER catalysts showed comparable or better specific activity per ECSA when compared to Ir and Ru catalysts in alk. solns., while most HER catalysts showed much lower specific activity than Pt in both acidic and alk. solns. For select catalysts, addnl. secondary screening measurements were conducted including faradaic efficiency and extended stability measurements.

The urgent need of clean and renewable energy drives the exploration of effective strategies to produce mol. hydrogen. With the assistance of highly active non-noble metal electrocatalysts, electrolysis of water is becoming a promising candidate to generate pure hydrogen with low cost and high efficiency. Very recently, transition metal phosphides (TMPs) have been proven to be high performance catalysts with high activity, high stability, and nearly ∼100% Faradic efficiency in not only strong acidic solns., but also in strong alk. and neutral media for electrochem. hydrogen evolution. In this tutorial review, an overview of recent development of TMP nanomaterials as catalysts for hydrogen generation with high activity and stability is presented. The effects of phosphorus (P) on HER activity, and their synthetic methods of TMPs are briefly discussed. Then we will demonstrate the specific strategies to further improve the catalytic efficiency and stability of TMPs by structural engineering. Making use of TMPs as cocatalysts and catalysts in photochem. and photoelectrochem. water splitting is also discussed. Finally, some key challenges and issues which should not be ignored during the rapid development of TMPs are pointed out. These strategies and challenges of TMPs are instructive for designing other high-performance non-noble metal catalysts.

The efficiency and stability of electrocatalysts are the key factors influencing the process of overall water splitting. In the research reported in this paper, the universal two-step method of co-pptn. and sulfuration is used to directly grow hierarchical nickel(II) hydroxide/trinickel disulfide [Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2] hybrid on nickel foam. The results show that the Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h material used as the three-dimensional (3D) substrate electrode can maximize the synergy between the Ni(OH)2 and Ni3S2, and it also exhibits high efficiency and persistent stability of the oxygen evolution reaction. The lower overpotential of only 270 mV at 20 mA cm-2 compared to the benchmark of iridium(IV) oxide electrodes (300 mV of overpotential at 20 mA cm-2) benefited from the particular hybrid structure of Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h with large voids and vol. and rapid charge transfer. In addn., the Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h material also shows a remarkable improved hydrogen evolution reaction activity compared to that of Ni(OH)2, Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-9h and Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-15h individual catalysts, with which a low overpotential of only 211 mV is achieved at 20 mA cm-2. Remarkably, Ni(OH)2/Ni3S2-12h is used as a bifunctional water splitting catalyst, with which an overpotential of ∼340 mV is acquired at a very low cell voltage of 1.57 V with 10 mA cm-2 in 1.0 M potassium hydroxide. These results demonstrate that most hydroxide/sulfide-based materials can be used as a electrocatalyst candidate and provide a superior synergy strategy, which provides a new way for robust water splitting electrochem. fabrication of high-performance and inexpensive electrode materials.

Transition metal phosphides recently have been identified as promising Earth-abundant electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Here, a general and scalable strategy is presented for the synthesis of transition metal phosphide electrodes based on the reaction of com. available metal foils (Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and NiFe) with various organophosphine reagents. The resulting phosphide electrodes were found to exhibit excellent electrocatalytic HER and OER performance. The most active electrodes required overpotentials of only -128 mV for the HER in acid (Ni2P), -183 mV for the HER in base (Ni2P), and 277 mV for the OER in base (NiFeP) to produce operationally relevant current densities of 10 mA cm-2. Such HER and OER performance compares favorably with samples prepd. using significantly more elaborate and costly procedures. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that the approach can also be utilized to obtain highly active and conformal metal phosphide coatings on photocathode materials, such as highly doped Si, that are relevant to solar fuels prodn.

For OER catalysis, a c.d. of 10 mA/cm2 requires an overpotential of only ∼320 mV and the slope of the Tafel plot is as low as 54 mV/dec in 1.0 M KOH. electrode is made of inexpensive and nonprecious metal-based materials, which opens new possibilities based on copper to exploit overall water splitting for hydrogen prodn. Although electrocatalysts based on transition metal phosphides (TMPs) with cationic/anionic doping have been widely studied for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the origin of performance enhancement still remains elusive mainly due to the random dispersion of dopants. Herein, a controllable partial phosphorization strategy is reported to generate CoP species within the Co-based metal-org. framework (Co-MOF). D. functional theory calcns. and exptl. results reveal that the electron transfer from CoP to Co-MOF through N-P/N-Co bonds could lead to the optimized adsorption energy of H2O (ΔGH2O*) and hydrogen (ΔGH*), which, together with the unique porous structure of Co-MOF, contributes to the remarkable HER performance with an overpotential of 49 mV at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2 in 1 M phosphate buffer soln. (PBS, pH 7.0). The excellent catalytic performance exceeds almost all the documented TMP-based and non-noble-metal-based electrocatalysts. In addn., the CoP/Co-MOF hybrid also displays Pt-like performance in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, with the overpotentials of 27 and 34 mV, resp., at a c.d. of 10 mA cm-2.
